summary: This document is an email chain from March 2021 regarding scheduling a call to discuss the process for preserving and reviewing electronic communications (e-communications) for the prosecution team in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The emails involve Assistant United States Attorneys and law enforcement personnel coordinating to comply with Justice Manual requirements for evidence preservation and disclosure to the defense.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the email chain and the criminal case for which e-communications review procedures are being discussed.

persons.name: Detective NYPD
persons.role: Detective, NYPD FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force
persons.context: A law enforcement officer involved in the Maxwell case who indicates availability for a scheduling call regarding e-communications review.

connections.description: Working together as part of the prosecution team in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, coordinating on evidence preservation procedures.
The AUSA is part of the team prosecuting Ghislaine Maxwell, as indicated by the discussion of case procedures.

events.title: Scheduling call for e-communications review
events.description: Email exchange to schedule a call to discuss the process for preserving and reviewing electronic communications for the Ghislaine Maxwell prosecution, in compliance with Justice Manual requirements.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
keyFacts: The prosecution team in the Ghislaine Maxwell case was coordinating in March 2021 to establish procedures for preserving and reviewing electronic communications (e-communications) as required by the Justice Manual.

The requirements included preserving all substantive e-communications created by prosecution team members and all communications with lay witnesses, regardless of content, for potential disclosure to the defense.
The email chain shows coordination between Assistant United States Attorneys and law enforcement (NYPD/FBI task force) to ensure compliance with evidence preservation protocols.
The document references Justice Manual section JM 9-5.004, which governs e-communications in federal criminal cases.
